awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: COLLAB: Goal-driven Marine Autonomy with Application to Fisheries Science and Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine robots can be used to accurately map and track marine life, leading to a better interpretation of variability and migration patterns that are important to fisheries managers in marine protected areas (MPAs).  Principles of engineering and oceanography can be used to maximize the impact of a network of marine robots, but because fisheries managers, oceanographers, and roboticists have different perspectives and knowledge bases, it can be difficult to take advantage of cutting-edge research in each field without significant effort to translate among the groups. Researchers will develop a computational interface that translates human-specified missions of fisheries managers into multi-level planning for a fleet of marine robots to monitor fish populations in a dynamic coastal ocean environment. The system will be designed with input from fisheries managers through a series of workshops, and will be field-tested at Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary, a federally-managed MPA off the coast of Georgia.  The research will lead to more accurate and effective ways to monitor fish populations in MPAs, as well as breakthroughs in key areas of artificial intelligence and autonomous systems. Many of the results will be applicable to other smart and autonomous systems in challenging environments.  In addition, the project will train graduate students and broaden undergraduate education in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM), and offer a number of outreach activities, including working with the University of Georgia Marine Extension service to develop a summer camp for middle and high school students.

The project is focused on developing an intelligent physical system (IPS) that consists of a heterogeneous fleet of marine robots, cooperatively tracking fish movement and surveying the habitat with minimum request for human intervention. The IPS will translate the human-specified missions of fisheries managers into goal-driven task designs for each robot, and automatically generate executable plans for the networked mobile sensing agents. The system will autonomously and persistently collect in-situ measurements and acoustic detections of fish species while maintaining multi-scale data streams and constructing multiple spatial-temporal maps reflecting the conditions of the ecosystem. The research aims to discover the hotspots (e.g., spatial locations with sustained congregations of fish), as well as illuminate more information about how and when fish move among these hotspots. This goal is quite challenging due to a number of gaps between project needs and the state-of-art autonomy research. Researchers will address the challenges through new developments that accomplish three main tasks: (1) Developing the goal-driven marine autonomy for fish habitat survey, (2) realizing the goal-driven autonomy on physical systems, and (3) evaluating the developed framework through real-life field work, experiments, and data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Marine robots can be used to accurately map and track marine life, leading to a better interpretation of variability and migration patterns that are important to fisheries managers in marine protected areas (MPAs). The goal of this research project was to develop an intelligent physical system (IPS) consisting of a heterogeneous fleet of marine robots, cooperatively tracking fish movement and surveying the habitat with minimum request for human intervention.  In this collaborative research project with Georgia Tech, University of Georgia, and Wright State University, the Michigan State University (MSU) team contributed to the development and control of aquatic robots for marine applications, as well as to the development of distributed estimation and control algorithms for missions such as tracking acoustically tagged fish.

The project resulted in the development of generation-3 (Gen-3) gliding robotic fish. Gliding robotic fish can use both energy-efficient gliding and tail-enabled swimming for locomotion and maneuvering. Different from its predecessors, Gen-3 gliding robotic fish uses separate, modular, cylindrical pressure hulls for housing different functional units, such as batteries, actuation systems, and control electronics. This feature is expected to mitigate the pressure-induced hull compression issue and enable Gen-3 robots to dive much deeper than its previous counterparts. The project also established the feasibility of using gliding robotic fish as a mobile platform for acoustic receivers. Field experiments on Higgins Lake, Michigan, showed that a receiver mounted on gliding robotic fish can successfully detect the pings from a tag within distances comparable to stationary receivers.

The project led to a number of advanced control algorithms for aquatic robots to track the desired trajectories. Control of aquatic robots is in general challenging due to several factors: their dynamics are highly nonlinear and often times under-actuated, and they are subject to environmental disturbances such as flows and waves. One technique developed in this project that addresses the under-actuated challenge is backstepping control using modified tracking errors, where the convergence of the tracking errors for all trajectory components is established through two-time-scale analysis of singularly perturbed systems. Experiments were conducted to support the efficacy of the developed controllers.

The project also resulted in a distributed estimation algorithm for multiple robots to estimate the location of a moving target with so-called time-difference-of-arrival (TDOA) measurements. For example, when the ping from an acoustically tagged fish is detected by multiple robots, the time of detection (namely, the time of the arrival, or TOA, of the ping at the receiver) is different for each robot and depends on the distance between the robot and the fish. Of course, each robot does not know the time when the ping was generated from the tag. However, by exchanging the TOA information with each other, the robots can derive TDOA information. Conditions on the network topology for the stability of the distributed estimator were derived, and field experiments involving a network of unmanned surface vehicles were conducted to confirm the theoretical findings.

Collectively, the project resulted in 8 journal publications (5 published/accepted, 3 under review), 12 conference papers, 4 Ph.D. dissertations and one M.S. thesis. It provided training opportunities to 7 Ph.D. students (6 domestic, 3 from underrepresented groups), one M.S. student, and 2 undergraduate students. Finally, the project contributed to various K-12 outreach activities, such as demos at Future Spartan Engineers Preview Day and the annual VEX Robotics State Championship at MSU.


Last Modified: 07/27/2022
Modified by: Xiaobo Tan

Image
  • The generation-3 gliding robotic fish developed at Michigan State University.
    Eli Reifenrath
    Copyrighted
    Xiaobo Tan
    Generation-3 gliding robotic fish
